section.para: The ngx_http_limit_conn_module module is used to limit the number of connections per the defined key, in particular, the number of connections from a single IP address.
Not all connections are counted. A connection is counted only if it has a request processed by the server and the whole request header has already been read.

directive.name: limit_conn
directive.para: These directives are inherited from the previous level if and only if there are no limit_conn directives on the current level.

directive.name: limit_conn_log_level
directive.para: Sets the desired logging level for cases when the server limits the number of connections.

directive.name: limit_conn_status
directive.para: Sets the status code to return in response to rejected requests.

directive.name: limit_conn_zone
directive.para:
Sets parameters for a shared memory zone that will keep states for various keys. In particular, the state includes the current number of connections. The key can contain text, variables, and their combination. Requests with an empty key value are not accounted.
Prior to version 1.7.6, a key could contain exactly one variable.
Usage example:
limit_conn_zone $binary_remote_addr zone=addr:10m;
Here, a client IP address serves as a key. Note that instead of $remote_addr, the $binary_remote_addr variable is used here. The $remote_addr variable’s size can vary from 7 to 15 bytes. The stored state occupies either 32 or 64 bytes of memory on 32-bit platforms and always 64 bytes on 64-bit platforms. The $binary_remote_addr variable’s size is always 4 bytes for IPv4 addresses or 16 bytes for IPv6 addresses. The stored state always occupies 32 or 64 bytes on 32-bit platforms and 64 bytes on 64-bit platforms. One megabyte zone can keep about 32 thousand 32-byte states or about 16 thousand 64-byte states. If the zone storage is exhausted, the server will return the error to all further requests.

directive.name: limit_zone
directive.para:
This directive was made obsolete in version 1.1.8 and was removed in version 1.7.6. An equivalent directive with a changed syntax should be used instead:
limit_conn_zone $variable zone=name:size;
